full_text: Q What is your purpose in entering the United States at this time? A To study. Q How long do you expect to remain in the United States? A At most two and a half years. Q At the end of the two and a half years where will you go? A Go back to China. Q Do you have a home or business in China? A I have a home in China. Q Will your wife return with you to China? A Yes. Q Do you ever expect to enter the United States for permanent residence or to become a citizen of the United States? A No. Q Do you have any promise of employment upon your return to China? A Yes. Q What type of employment? A Engineering work and teaching. Q Do you care to state just what your financial means are? A About $5000.00 in gold, about $2500 here and $2500 in China. I also have a farm in China. QX Q Do you have any other letters or documents showing your intention to attend the University of Minnesoto? A Yes. Presents - Letter bearing letterhead of the University of Minnesoto, Graduate School, Minneapolis 14, Office of the Dean: May 28, 1946. "To Whom it May Concern: This is to certify that Mr. Maoling Liu has been previously registered in the Graduate School of the University of Minnesota, is in good standing, and we shall be very glad to have him reregister for the fall quarter of 1946. The Department of Physics is putting through an appointment for him as a teaching assistant on half-time with a salary of $787.50 for the academic year of three quarters, extending from September 16, 1946 through June 15, 1947. "We are greatly concerned to have Mr. Liu arrive on the campus in ample time to begin his teaching assistantship and studies as a graduate student. Anything which you can do to facilitate the matter will be very much appreciated." Presents - Telegram dated January 30, 1947, addressed to Mr. Hertogs, Immigration Service, San Francisco, California, as follows: 2/1/47 1300-47068 -5-
